text.p: The selling of the Sydney 2000 Olympics began on Tuesday with the first official Games T-shirt hitting the stores on New Year's Eve with a price tag of A$150 (US$119).

In what will be a four-year promotional campaign to help fund the Summer Olympics, organisers will sell everything from T-shirts and babies' bibs to socks and pins, all embossed with the Sydney Olympics logo.
But while an embroidered collector's edition T-shirt is priced at A$150, other T-shirts will range from A$30 to A$50 and a baby's bib retails for A$13.
The marketing push begins officially on the first day of 1997, the start of the Sydney Olympic quadrennium when sponsors can promote their association with the 2000 Games.
Olympic organisers on Tuesday announced 17 major sponsors would contribute more than A$500 million in cash and services.
Organisers hope to raise A$2.4 billion in total sponsorship and sales, with television rights contributing A$1.2 billion.
"We have achieved this in much less time than we thought," organising committee chief executive Mal Hemmerling said. "Sydney sits better than any other Olympic Games in history."

Organisers hope to close their major sponsors programme by mid-1997 with about 22 companies, half the number in Atlanta, in line with a strategy to reduce sponsor numbers and boost value. Global giants to take out worldwide rights for the Sydney Olympics include traditional Olympic supporters such as Coca-Cola, McDonalds, IBM and Visa.
Fuji Xerox, United Parcel Service, Kodak, Panasonic and Time have also signed up, along with eight national partners which will have Australian sponsorship rights.
Organisers would not say what each company would be paying for the sponsorship deal, but said the minimum floor set by the organising committee was around A$25 million.
